bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, July 17, 1854

div1.p: Tate is surprised at the length of the questionnaire from Hench but will answer the questions to the best of his ability.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, July 17, 1854
div1.opener:
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley, California
July 17, 1854
Philip S. Hench, M.D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
The box of material came today, and the word
surprised would not have been adequate when I saw the
contents!

But don't think I'm scared. As long as I don't
have to rush I will tackle it with interest and give all
the time I can to it.

I notice that Mrs. Bruce charged an extortinate
price for her work. My idea would be for me to type all
the answers to your questions in carbon duplicate, num-
bering each answer with the question number. Then, with
my duplicate and the question sheet you said I may keep,
there would be no necessity of an further copy for me.
You could then have it put in corrective form in Rochester
much cheaper than here. Of course, I will do it any way
you wish, with the exception of tape recorder, having had
no experience with them.

The only thing I regret is I see by my first
quick reading there are going to be many blanks on these
questions. You know that no one person concerned in the
experiment could possibly give an answer to all those
questions about so many people in so many places at many
different times, but be assured I'll tell you all I know
of my own knowledge and what I have heard directly.

I notice in some questions, you say, “make a guess.”
In some instances, say, such as number of sick civilians
in Pinar del Rio, I have no factual basis to make an intel-
ligent guess. I have thought of something else, so I may as
well make this a sort of preliminary statement so that you
may know how I will try to answer the questions. It is in
relation to memory. Many people besides old Samuel Johnson
have found that human evidence is very untrustworthy.

As an example in my own case in relation to Y. F.
subject: I took the phone message from Havana to tell Capt.
Godfrey there was to be an inquiry into the suspicious num-
ber of deaths at his hospital. As I remembered it, the voice
said: “This is Major Gorgas' headquarters.” Sometime after-
ward I knew that such a message should not have originated
(2)
in that office, and further learned that Capt. Stark was
then acting in place of Surg. Gen. Western Cuba at that
time. So I knew that my “distinct remembrance” was wrong,
yet that is the way I still remember the incident!

Again: I wrote you once about how easy it was to
get to Camp Lazear. At that time I was writing of Camp
Lazear, a place I had been to but once, and rode there in
an ambulance, but was really thinking and describing how
to walk to the fever section across the track, and even
then made the distance too long.

So, anything I say, especially on a controversial
subject, check carefully, for while I will do my best I re-
alize these twists of memory may still play tricks on me.
Especially is this so, as I have to try to eliminate from
my mind all the things I have heard and read on the same
subject.

I am still not convinced that my evidence can be
of much real value, but as you have honored me with the
task I will carry through as if it were, and begin on it
tomorrow. As I get batches sufficient to mail I will send
then on to you. With best wishes,
